channel.title: Legit RS Client In Java?
channel.description:
I'm just wondering if this is possible. I know it wont look as good as VB clients but a Java client could have a lot more usefulness/features. I was just wondering if this was possible, for it to be legitimate, yet effective.
If I wanted to make it break the rules, but not be a bot, just give an unfair advantage, would it be hard to make it undetectable, or less detectable.
Code snippets/Ideas/Tutorials/Anything I should know would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks x

item.title: Legit RS Client In Java?
item.dc:creator: @Whiskey Whiskey
item.description:
@Whiskey wrote:

regecks`:

I think the problem is that Jagex aren’t going to approve of a client that emulates the browser, rather than implementing the browser, and will jump at any chance to ban its users.

Hence, why I asked whether, if JaGeX didn’t approve of it, to make is undetectable to them

Mopman:

It’s not too difficult to make use of ActiveX controls in Java, meaning you could use the IE control like most VB clients do, or the Mozilla ActiveX if you prefer, and make a legal client. However, this would limit you to Windows and kind of defeats the purpose.

I have a look in to using the ActiveX controls, but yes, it does only limit it to Windows. I suppose that isn’t such a big problem, but it would be nice for a OS independant client.

Krichevskoy:

Sure you can, and it can be legitimate, if not exactly supported by Jagex. URLClassLoader, JFrame, and AppletStub are the classes you’ll need. Check out any of the “Loader” topics for examples (though some of those might not use URLClassLoader, which I think would be the easiest way to have a legit client).

Thanks again I’ll have a wee look in to the classes and try and implement them. Once of got a basic client, I’ll try and expand.

Thanks for the help you guys.

Read full topic
